side_a: What are the main arteries supplying the pancreas?
side_b: The pancreas receives blood from the splenic artery, the superior pancreaticoduodenal artery (from the gastroduodenal artery), and the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery (from the superior mesenteric artery).

side_a: What is the venous drainage of the pancreas?
side_b: The venous drainage of the pancreas occurs through the pancreatic veins, which drain into the splenic vein and the superior mesenteric vein, eventually forming the portal vein.

side_a: Which artery supplies the head of the pancreas?
side_b: The head of the pancreas is supplied by the superior pancreaticoduodenal artery (from the gastroduodenal artery) and the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery (from the superior mesenteric artery).

side_a: Which artery supplies the body and tail of the pancreas?
side_b: The body and tail of the pancreas are primarily supplied by branches of the splenic artery.

side_a: What is the origin of the superior pancreaticoduodenal artery?
side_b: The superior pancreaticoduodenal artery originates from the gastroduodenal artery.

side_a: What is the origin of the inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery?
side_b: The inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery originates from the superior mesenteric artery.

side_a: What is the significance of the anastomosis between the pancreaticoduodenal arteries?
side_b: The anastomosis between the superior and inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries provides collateral circulation between the celiac trunk and the superior mesenteric artery.

side_a: Which veins drain the head of the pancreas?
side_b: The head of the pancreas is drained by the pancreaticoduodenal veins, which drain into the superior mesenteric vein and portal vein.

side_a: Which veins drain the body and tail of the pancreas?
side_b: The body and tail of the pancreas are drained by the pancreatic veins, which empty into the splenic vein.

side_a: Which lymph nodes receive lymphatic drainage from the pancreas?
side_b: Lymphatic drainage from the pancreas goes to the pancreaticosplenic, pyloric, hepatic, and superior mesenteric lymph nodes.

side_a: What is the sympathetic innervation of the pancreas?
side_b: The pancreas receives sympathetic innervation from the greater and lesser splanchnic nerves via the celiac and superior mesenteric plexuses.

side_a: What is the parasympathetic innervation of the pancreas?
side_b: The pancreas receives parasympathetic innervation from the vagus nerve (CN X).

side_a: How does sympathetic stimulation affect the pancreas?
side_b: Sympathetic stimulation inhibits pancreatic secretion and promotes vasoconstriction.

side_a: How does parasympathetic stimulation affect the pancreas?
side_b: Parasympathetic stimulation increases pancreatic enzyme and bicarbonate secretion.

side_a: What is the role of the celiac plexus in pancreatic innervation?
side_b: The celiac plexus provides autonomic innervation to the pancreas, including sympathetic fibers from the greater splanchnic nerve and parasympathetic fibers from the vagus nerve.

side_a: What is the role of the superior mesenteric plexus in pancreatic innervation?
side_b: The superior mesenteric plexus supplies autonomic fibers to the pancreas, mainly affecting the head of the pancreas.

side_a: Which nerve carries visceral pain sensation from the pancreas?
side_b: Visceral pain sensation from the pancreas is carried by afferent fibers traveling with the sympathetic nerves (greater splanchnic nerve).

side_a: What is the main neurotransmitter involved in sympathetic innervation of the pancreas?
side_b: The main neurotransmitter for sympathetic innervation of the pancreas is norepinephrine.

side_a: What is the main neurotransmitter involved in parasympathetic innervation of the pancreas?
side_b: The main neurotransmitter for parasympathetic innervation of the pancreas is acetylcholine.

side_a: How do the autonomic nerves reach the pancreas?
side_b: Autonomic nerves reach the pancreas through the celiac and superior mesenteric plexuses, which follow the blood vessels.

side_a: What is the embryological origin of the pancreas?
side_b: The pancreas develops from the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds of the foregut.

side_a: What is the function of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas?
side_b: The islets of Langerhans are responsible for endocrine functions, including insulin, glucagon, and somatostatin secretion.

side_a: Which pancreatic cells produce insulin?
side_b: Beta cells in the islets of Langerhans produce insulin.

side_a: Which pancreatic cells produce glucagon?
side_b: Alpha cells in the islets of Langerhans produce glucagon.

side_a: Which pancreatic cells produce somatostatin?
side_b: Delta cells in the islets of Langerhans produce somatostatin.

side_a: What type of epithelium lines the pancreatic ducts?
side_b: The pancreatic ducts are lined by simple cuboidal to columnar epithelium.

side_a: What is the histological structure of pancreatic acini?
side_b: Pancreatic acini are composed of pyramidal-shaped exocrine cells with basophilic cytoplasm due to abundant rough endoplasmic reticulum.

side_a: Which enzyme-secreting cells are found in the pancreas?
side_b: Pancreatic acinar cells secrete digestive enzymes, including amylase, lipase, and proteases (trypsinogen, chymotrypsinogen).

side_a: How does the pancreas prevent self-digestion by its enzymes?
side_b: The pancreas secretes proteases in inactive forms (zymogens), which are activated only in the duodenum.

side_a: What is the role of the pancreatic duct?
side_b: The pancreatic duct transports digestive enzymes and bicarbonate to the duodenum.

side_a: What is the accessory pancreatic duct?
side_b: The accessory pancreatic duct (duct of Santorini) is a secondary duct that may drain into the minor duodenal papilla.

side_a: Where does the main pancreatic duct empty?
side_b: The main pancreatic duct (duct of Wirsung) empties into the duodenum at the major duodenal papilla.

side_a: Which structure controls the release of pancreatic secretions into the duodenum?
side_b: The sphincter of Oddi controls the release of pancreatic secretions into the duodenum.

side_a: What is the effect of secretin on the pancreas?
side_b: Secretin stimulates the pancreas to secrete bicarbonate-rich fluid.

side_a: What is the effect of cholecystokinin (CCK) on the pancreas?
side_b: Cholecystokinin (CCK) stimulates the pancreas to secrete enzyme-rich fluid.

side_a: What is pancreatic stellate cell activation associated with?
side_b: Pancreatic stellate cell activation is associated with fibrosis in chronic pancreatitis.

side_a: What histological feature distinguishes endocrine from exocrine pancreas?
side_b: The endocrine pancreas (islets of Langerhans) lacks ducts, whereas the exocrine pancreas (acini) has extensive ductal structures.

side_a: What staining characteristic differentiates pancreatic acinar cells from islet cells?
side_b: Pancreatic acinar cells have a basophilic cytoplasm due to abundant rough ER, while islet cells stain lighter due to their endocrine nature.
